text: X-linked myopathy with excessive autophagy is a type of X-linked recessive disease that is characterized by childhood onset of progressive muscle weakness and atrophy primarily affecting the proximal muscles in males between 5 and 10 years old, has a material basis in mutation in the VMA21 gene on chromosome Xq28.

Adenylosuccinase lyase deficiency is a type of amino acid metabolic disorder characterized by microcephaly, aggressive behavior, cerebellar hypoplasia, and seizures. It has a material basis in autosomal recessive inheritance, resulting from mutation in the ADSL gene that leads to adenylosuccinate lyase deficiency.

Arc syndrome, also known as Arthrogryposis-renal dysfunction-cholestasis (ARC) syndrome, is a rare genetic disorder that affects multiple systems in the body. It is characterized by congenital joint contractures, renal tubular dysfunction, cholestasis, severe failure to thrive, ichthyosis, and defective platelet alpha-granule biogenesis. The condition is caused by mutations in either the VPS33B gene or the VIPAR gene, which are located on chromosome 14q24.3. ARC syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder, meaning that a person must inherit two copies of the gene (one from each parent) to develop the condition. It can cause a range of health issues and complications in affected individuals, including developmental delays, intellectual disability, and an increased risk of certain types of cancer.

Armfield syndrome is a type of X-linked intellectual disability characterized by intellectual disability, short stature, seizures, and small hands and feet. It is caused by variation in the chromosomal region Xq28.

Neuroacanthocytosis is a rare neurodegenerative disease that affects the brain and spinal cord. It is characterized by misshapen, spiny red blood cells (acanthocytosis) and neurological abnormalities, especially movement disorders.

Chorea-acanthocytosis is a type of autosomal recessive disease that causes progressive neurodegeneration and red cell acanthocytosis. It has a material basis in mutations in the VPS13A gene on chromosome 9q21, which encodes chorein. The condition is also known as Levine-Critchley syndrome and choreo-acanthocytosis.

Midface dysplasia is a type of osteochondrodysplasia that affects the development of the midface area, which includes the cheekbones and the bones around the nose. It can cause various facial abnormalities such as hypertelorism (widely spaced eyes), a wide nose, vertical midline cleft, and encephalocele (a protrusion of the brain through an opening in the skull). It is important to note that while this condition affects the appearance of the face, it does not typically result in significant functional impairments. However, it can be associated with other health issues such as hearing loss, vision problems, and dental abnormalities.
Mitochondrial complex V (ATP synthase) deficiency nuclear type 1 is a condition that occurs due to mutations in the ATPAF2 gene on chromosome 17p11.

NXXX syndrome, also known as Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), is a genetic disorder that affects the development of the nervous system. It is characterized by the growth of tumors called neurofibromas on nerves and skin.

Other common symptoms of NXXX syndrome may include freckling in the axillary (armpit) area, Lisch nodules in the eye, and bone deformities such as scoliosis or leg length inequality. In some cases, individuals with NXXX syndrome may also have other health issues like hypertension (high blood pressure), learning disabilities, or an increased risk of certain types of cancer.

It is important to note that while the term "NXXX" is sometimes used informally to refer to this condition, it is actually a type of NF1, which is one of several subtypes of Neurofibromatosis.

Polycystic liver disease (PCLD) is a type of autosomal dominant liver disease characterized by the presence of multiple cysts in the liver. It has an exact synonym of congenital cystic liver disease and congenital hepatic cyst, but it does not have any specific material basis for its inheritance. This means that if one parent has PCLD, there is a 50% chance that their child will inherit the condition. It is important to note that while PCLD can lead to liver enlargement and complications, it is generally less severe than other forms of liver disease.

Pheochromocytoma is a type of endocrine organ benign neoplasm that arises within the adrenal medulla, releasing epinephrines and norepinephrines hormones that cause either episodic or persistent high blood pressure.

Spastic ataxia 1 is a type of autosomal dominant disease characterized by early-onset cerebellar ataxia, spasticity, pyramidal syndrome and peripheral neuropathy. It has a material basis in the autosomal dominant inheritance of heterozygous mutation in the VAMP1 gene on chromosome 12p13.

Paraganglioma is a type of tumor that occurs in the extraadrenal sympathetic ganglia, which are clusters of nerve cells located outside of the adrenal glands. These tumors can be benign or malignant and can cause symptoms such as hypertension, headache, and sweating. Paraganglioma is also known by its synonyms chemodectoma, glomus body tumor, and pheochromocytoma.

Rapadilino syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that affects multiple body systems. It is characterized by radial ray defect, patellae hypoplasia, cleft palate, diarrhea, dislocated joints, limb malformations, and a long nose. Additionally, affected individuals typically have normal intelligence. The syndrome has a material basis in homozygous or compound heterozygous mutations in the DNA helicase gene RECQL4, which is located on chromosome 8q24.

Schneckenbecken dysplasia is a type of osteochondrodysplasia. Osteochondrodysplasias are a group of genetic disorders that affect bone growth and development. They can cause various skeletal abnormalities, such as short stature, bowed legs, and deformities in the hands and feet. Schneckenbecken dysplasia is characterized by hypoplastic iliac bones, hypoplastic vertebral bodies, short ribs, and broad long bones. It is usually prenatally lethal, meaning that it is usually fatal before birth. It has a genetic basis, with homozygous or compound heterozygous mutations in the SLC35D1 gene on chromosome 1p31 being the cause.

Non-syndromic X-linked intellectual disability, also known as non-specific X-linked mental retardation, is a type of intellectual disability characterized by a pattern of inheritance on the X chromosome. It occurs when there is a mutation in one of the genes located on the X chromosome, which can lead to cognitive impairment.
It's worth noting that this type of intellectual disability does not have any specific set of symptoms or features, unlike syndromic intellectual disabilities, which are associated with certain physical and developmental abnormalities. However, it may still impact various aspects of a person's life, including their cognitive function, motor skills, and social interactions.
It is important to note that non-syndromic X-linked intellectual disability can have varying degrees of severity, ranging from mild to severe. Early intervention and support from professionals, such as genetic counselors, psychologists, and educational specialists, can help individuals with this condition reach their full potential and improve their quality of life.

Joubert syndrome is indeed a type of ciliopathy, which refers to a group of disorders caused by defects in cilia, which are small, hair-like structures that line the surfaces of various organs and cavities within the body. In the case of Joubert syndrome, these defects can lead to abnormal development of the brainstem and cerebellum, resulting in a range of symptoms such as respiratory problems, nystagmus (involuntary eye movements), hypotonia (low muscle tone), ataxia (difficulty with coordination and balance), and delayed motor milestones. It's worth noting that Joubert syndrome is also known by its abbreviation, JBTS.

Meckel syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that affects multiple systems of the body. It is characterized by the presence of renal cystic dysplasia, occipital encephalocele, polydactyly (post axial), hepatic developmental defects, and pulmonary hypoplasia. The disorder is classified as a ciliopathy, which are a group of genetic disorders caused by mutations in the cilia or basal body, structures that play an important role in various cellular processes such as motility, signaling, and differentiation.
Meckel-Gruber syndrome is another name for Meckel syndrome, which is used interchangeably to describe the disorder. It is essential to note that the exact cause of Meckel syndrome is not yet fully understood, but researchers believe it may be caused by mutations in the IFT88 gene, which plays a role in cilia function and regulation.
Treatment for Meckel syndrome typically focuses on managing the symptoms and complications of the disorder. This may include surgery to remove cysts or other growths, as well as monitoring and addressing any developmental delays or other health issues that arise. Early diagnosis and intervention are crucial in ensuring the best possible outcomes for individuals with Meckel syndrome.

Hydrolethalus syndrome is a type of autosomal recessive disease characterized by multiple fetal developmental defects including polydactyly and central nervous system malformations that results from a single amino acid mutation of D211G of the HYLS1 gene which plays a central role in cilia formation. It has an exact synonym Salonen-Herva-Norio syndrome.

Ogden Syndrome, also known as N-alpha-acetyltransferase deficiency or X-linked Malformation and Infantile Lethality Syndrome, is a rare genetic disorder characterized by postnatal growth failure, severely delayed psychomotor development, variable dysmorphic features, and hypotonia. It is caused by a mutation in the NAA10 gene on chromosome Xq28.

Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES) is a rare condition that involves the production of excessive amounts of stomach acid due to the presence of tumors in the pancreas or duodenum. These tumors, known as gastrinomas, produce an excess of the hormone gastrin, which stimulates the production of acid by the stomach. The syndrome is named after two doctors who first described it: Frederick J. Zollinger and John L. Ellison.
SPMS, or Secondary-Progressive MS, is a type of multiple sclerosis characterized by steadily worsening disability without relapses and remissions.

Primary Progressive Multiple Sclerosis (PPMS) is a type of multiple sclerosis characterized by steadily worsening neurological function over time, without any distinct relapses or periods of remission. The rate of progression may vary and there may be occasional plateaus or temporary improvements, but the overall progression is continuous. It is also known as Primary-Progressive MS (PPMS).

Progressive-relapsing multiple sclerosis (PRMS) is a type of multiple sclerosis characterized by steadily worsening symptoms and attacks during periods of remission with disease progression from the onset. It has exact synonyms such as PRMS, Progressive-relapsing MS, and MESH:D020528.

Iridogoniodysgenesis syndrome is a type of iris disease that is characterized by the iris stroma being hypoplastic resulting from abnormalities in the differentiation of the anterior segment structures and increased values of intraocular pressure. It has a material basis in autosomal dominant inheritance of mutations in the PITX2 gene, and it can be referred to as IGDS, IRID 1, IRID 2, iridogoniodysgenesis type 1, or iridogoniodysgenesis type 2.

Juvenile polyposis syndrome (JPS) is a type of autosomal dominant gastrointestinal disorder that affects the stomach, small intestine, colon, and rectum. It is characterized by an increased risk of developing benign hamartomatous polyps, which are non-cancerous growths in the gastrointestinal tract. JPS typically presents during childhood or adolescence and can lead to complications if left untreated. The exact cause of JPS is not known, but it is believed to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treatment for JPS generally involves surgical removal of the polyps to prevent them from becoming cancerous.

Proximal symphalangism is a type of autosomal dominant disease characterized by ankylosis of the proximal interphalangeal joints, carpal and tarsal bone fusion, and conductive deafness. It has exact synonym Cushing's symphalangism.

Tarsal carpal coalition syndrome is a type of autosomal dominant disease that is characterized by the fusion of the carpals, tarsals, and phalanges, leading to brachydactyly (short first metacarpals) and humeroradial fusion. It has a material basis in some form of autosomal dominant inheritance.

Fibular hypoplasia and complex brachydactyly is a type of autosomal recessive disease that is characterized by severe reduction or absence of the fibula and complex brachydactyly. It has been described as acromesomelic dysplasia, which is a type of dysplasia that affects the development of bones in the hands and feet. The exact synonyms for this condition include Du Pan syndrome and acromesomelic dysplasia-2B.

Persistent Mullerian duct syndrome, also known as pseudohermaphroditism, is a condition where the reproductive organs of an individual do not develop properly. This can include genitalia that resembles both male and female characteristics. The exact cause of this condition is unknown, but it can occur due to genetic or environmental factors. It is important for those affected by this condition to consult with their healthcare provider to discuss the best course of action for treatment and management.

Multiple cutaneous and mucosal venous malformations (MCMV) is a type of autosomal dominant skin disease. It is characterized by multiple bluish cutaneous or mucosal venous lesions that have a material basis in heterozygous mutation in the TEK gene on chromosome 9p21. MCMV has exact synonyms such as VMCM, cutaneomucosal venous malformation, and mucocutaneous venous malformations.

Short QT Syndrome (SQTS) is a type of heart conduction disease characterized by an abnormality in the electrical activity of the heart, resulting in shortened duration of the QT interval on electrocardiograms. This condition can cause various arrhythmias and increase the risk of sudden death. It is often inherited and may be triggered by certain medications or conditions such as diabetes or hypothyroidism. SQTS is typically diagnosed through an EKG that shows a short QT interval, along with other signs like tall T-waves and a structurally normal heart. Treatment for SQTS may involve medications to manage the arrhythmias and prevent sudden death, as well as lifestyle changes such as avoiding triggers and maintaining a healthy weight.

Multiple synostoses syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that affects the bones in the hands and feet. It is characterized by the premature fusion of multiple bone epiphyses, which are the growth plates located at the ends of long bones where new bone tissue grows. This can lead to problems with mobility and deformities in the affected limbs. Additionally, people with this disorder may also experience conductive deafness and characteristic facial features, such as a broad, tubular-shaped nose and a thin upper vermilion. It is important to note that multiple synostoses syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder, meaning that it can be passed down through generations of a family and affect multiple members.

Cone dystrophy is a condition that affects the cone cells in the retina, which are responsible for central and color vision. It can cause progressive vision loss and is often inherited. Treatment options may include glasses, low vision aids, or gene therapy.

Achalasia microcephaly syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that affects the brain development and causes microcephaly, intellectual disability, and other health issues. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, which means that it is passed down through genes from both parents and requires the expression of two copies of the gene to develop the condition. Symptoms typically appear in early infancy and include a small head size (microcephaly), developmental delays or intellectual disability, difficulty swallowing (achalasia), recurrent vomiting, and respiratory infections. The underlying cause is not well understood, but researchers believe that it may be related to defects in brain development or genetic mutations. There is no cure for Achalasia microcephaly syndrome, but early intervention and management can help improve quality of life for affected individuals.

peroxisomal acyl coa oxidase deficiency has symptoms such as low tone and seizures in babies.

Cerebral creatine deficiency syndrome is a type of amino acid metabolic disorder that affects the brain and is caused by mutations in the creatine transporter gene on chromosome Xq28. It is characterized by mental retardation, severe speech delay, behavioral abnormalities, and seizures.

guanidinoacetate methyltransferase deficiency is a rare genetic disorder that affects the production of creatine, which is an important energy source for the brain. It can cause severe intellectual disability, seizures, speech problems, and involuntary movements. The condition is caused by mutations in the GAMT gene on chromosome 19p13.
guanidinoacetate methyltransferase deficiency is also known as cerebral creatine deficiency syndrome 2 and GAMT deficiency.

Cerebral Creatine Deficiency Syndrome 1 is a rare genetic disorder characterized by mental retardation, severe speech delay, behavioral abnormalities, and seizures. It is caused by mutations in the SLC6A8 gene on chromosome Xq28. This condition is also known as CEREBRAL CREATINE DEFICIENCY SYNDROME 1, SLC6A8 deficiency, and creatine transporter deficiency.

Androgenic alopecia, also known as male pattern baldness, is a common form of hair loss that occurs due to the action of the hormone dihydrotestosterone (DHT) on the hair follicles. It typically starts with recession at the temples and crown, causing an M-shaped hairline. The condition often affects men as they age, but it can also affect women. Treatment options include minoxidil, finasteride, and hair transplant surgery.

Ehlers Danlos Syndrome, Progeroid Type 2 (EDSP2) is a type of Ehlers Danlos Syndrome characterized by an aged appearance, developmental delay, short stature, craniofacial disproportion, generalized osteopenia, defective wound healing, hypermobile joints, hypotonic muscles, and loose but elastic skin. It has a material basis in compound heterozygosity of mutations in the B3GALT6 gene. This condition is autosomal recessive, meaning that to have this syndrome, an individual must inherit two copies of the gene, one from each parent.

A glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) is a type of glioblastoma that is characterized by the expression of several gene types that are also typical of the brain's normal, noncancerous nerve cells, or neurons.

Kahrizi syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that primarily affects the brain and eyes. It is caused by mutations in the SRD5A3 gene, which is located on the X chromosome. The symptoms of Kahrizi syndrome include intellectual disability, cataracts, coloboma (a type of eye abnormality), kyphosis (a forward curvature of the spine), and coarse facial features. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, which means that a person must inherit two copies of the gene (one from each parent) to develop the condition. There is no cure for Kahrizi syndrome, but early intervention and management can help improve the quality of life for those affected by the disorder.

Mucopolysaccharidosis IX, also known as Sly Syndrome, is a rare genetic disorder characterized by a deficiency in the enzyme hyaluronidase. This leads to an excess buildup of mucin and other glycosaminoglycans, causing various symptoms such as progressive short stature, skeletal abnormalities, and multiple joint contractures. It is caused by mutations in the HYAL1 gene, which is located on chromosome 3. Treatment options may include enzyme replacement therapy, bone marrow transplantation, or surgical interventions to address specific symptoms.

Biotin is a B-complex vitamin, also known as Vitamin H, that plays an important role in the metabolism of carbohydrates, fats, and amino acids. It is essential for cell growth, the production of fatty acids, and the maintenance of healthy skin, hair, eyes, and nails. A deficiency in biotin can lead to various symptoms such as thinning of hair (sometimes accompanied by loss of hair color), dry and rough skin, brittle nails, and weakness. Biotin is found in a variety of foods including yeast, eggs, milk, cheese, liver, and some types of grains. It can also be taken as a supplement to ensure adequate intake.

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) is a group of genetic disorders that affect the adrenal glands. The adrenal glands are small endocrine glands located on top of each kidney. They produce various hormones, such as cortisol and aldosterone, which help regulate bodily functions like blood pressure, heart rate, and immune response.

CAH occurs when the enzymes responsible for producing these hormones are missing or do not work properly. As a result, the adrenal glands produce too much or too little of these hormones, leading to a range of health problems. The severity of symptoms varies depending on the type of CAH and which enzyme is affected.

There are two main types of CAH: salt-wasting (due to deficiency in 21-hydroxylase) and glucocorticoid-remediable (due to deficiency in 3-beta-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase). Salt-wasting CAH causes the body to excrete too much sodium, leading to low blood pressure and other complications. In contrast, glucocorticoid-remediable CAH can be treated with a steroid medication that replaces the missing hormones, allowing the body to function normally.

It's important for individuals with CAH to work closely with their healthcare providers to manage their symptoms and ensure proper treatment. This may include regular monitoring of blood pressure, hormone levels, and other bodily functions. With proper care and management, people with CAH can lead a relatively normal life.

Spondyloepimetaphyseal dysplasia Pakistani type is a genetic disorder that affects the development of bones and joints. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, which means it is passed down through families and can affect people regardless of their gender.
People with this condition may have short stature, bowed legs, brachydactyly (shortened arms), kyphoscoliosis ( curvature of the spine), abnormal gait, enlarged knee joints, and precocious osteoarthropathy. These symptoms can lead to a range of mobility issues and discomfort.
Despite these challenges, people with Spondyloepimetaphyseal dysplasia Pakistani type are often intelligent and have normal intelligence. This condition is not contagious, and there is no cure for it. However, early intervention and treatment can help manage the symptoms and improve quality of life.

Temtamy preaxial brachydactyly syndrome is a type of autosomal recessive disease that affects the development of various body parts, including the hands and feet. It is characterized by brachydactyly (short fingers and toes), hyperphalangism (an abnormal bone condition involving an excessively bent or "toe-thumb" relationship), facial dysmorphism (abnormal facial features), dental anomalies, sensorineural hearing loss, delayed motor and mental development, and growth retardation. It is caused by a mutation in the CHSY1 gene. This syndrome has been named after Dr. Temtamy, who first described it. The exact synonym of this condition is "Preaxial brachydactyly syndrome, Temtamy type."

Urofacial syndrome (also known as Ochoa syndrome) is a rare genetic disorder that affects the development of the urinary tract and facial features. It is characterized by severe and early-onset dysfunctional urinary voiding, which can lead to complications such as hydronephrosis (swelling of the kidneys). The syndrome is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, meaning that it requires the presence of two copies of the mutated gene for its expression. Patients with urofacial syndrome often have distinct facial features, including a characteristic inverted smile or frowning facial expression. Treatment typically focuses on managing symptoms and preventing complications, such as hydronephrosis. Surgical intervention may be required in some cases to alleviate the effects of the syndrome.
Stargardt disease is a type of age-related macular degeneration that causes progressive vision loss, often leading to legal blindness. It has the exact synonym "Stargardt Disease 1."

Transcobalamin II deficiency is a type of vitamin B12 deficiency that occurs due to a lack of intestinal absorption of vitamin B12 caused by a deficiency in the TCII protein. This results in an insufficient amount of active vitamin B12 being available for the body's needs, leading to various health issues if left untreated.

atrioventricular block is a type of heart conduction disease characterized by the impairment of the conduction between the atria and ventricles of the heart. It has also been referred to as AV block. The term atrioventricular block can be used interchangeably with AV block, and it has been matched with the MESH term D054537.

First-degree atrioventricular block (AV block) is a type of cardiac conduction system block. It is characterized by a prolonged PR interval on the electrocardiogram, which is due to delayed conduction from the atria to the ventricles through the AV node. This condition is often benign and does not require any treatment unless it becomes complete or second-degree AV block occurs.

Second-degree atrioventricular block (AVB) is a type of heart block where there is a progressive prolongation of the PR interval on consecutive beats, followed by a blocked P wave on electrocardiogram or intermittently non-conducted P waves not preceded by PR changes on electrocardiogram due to conduction block between the atria and ventricles through the AV node. It is also known as second-degree heart block.

Third-degree atrioventricular block, also known as complete atrioventricular block, is a type of heart block characterized by a disruption in the conduction of electrical signals between the atria and ventricles. This leads to a slowing of the heart rate and can cause symptoms such as dizziness, lightheadedness, and palpitations. It is typically diagnosed through an electrocardiogram (ECG) and treated with a pacemaker or other medical interventions.

Sinoatrial node disease, also known as sinus node disease or SA node disease, refers to a heart condition where the sinoatrial (SA) node, which is responsible for generating normal sinus rhythm in the heart, experiences dysfunction. This can lead to an irregular heartbeat or even complete heart block, depending on the severity of the disease. Sinoatrial node disease is a type of muscular disease and heart conduction disease, characterized by impaired functioning of the pacemaker tissue in the right atrium of the heart.

Endocarditis is a type of heart disease that occurs when the inner lining of the heart (the endocardium) becomes infected. It can also involve the outer layer of the heart (the myocardium). Endocarditis is usually caused by bacteria that enter the bloodstream and become attached to the heart valves or other parts of the heart. Symptoms may include fever, chest pain, shortness of breath, and fatigue. Treatment typically involves antibiotics and, in some cases, surgery to remove infected tissue or replace damaged heart valves.

Tricuspid valve disease is a type of heart valve disease that affects the tricuspid valve located between the right atrium and right ventricle. It can cause valvular insufficiency or stenosis, leading to various symptoms such as shortness of breath, fatigue, and swelling in the legs and feet. Tricuspid valve disease is often caused by rheumatic heart disease, which is an autoimmune disorder that affects the heart valves. Other causes of tricuspid valve disease include congenital heart defects, infectious diseases such as endocarditis, and certain medications. Treatment options for tricuspid valve disease depend on the underlying cause and severity of the condition, but may include medication, surgery, or a combination of both.

Rheumatic heart disease, also known as rheumatic carditis, is a type of heart valve disease that is characterized by repeated inflammation with fibrinous repair caused by an autoimmune reaction to Group A beta-hemolytic streptococci (GAS) that results in valvular damage. The cardinal anatomic changes of the valve include leaflet thickening, commissural fusion, and shortening and thickening of the tendinous cords.

artery disease is a type of vascular disease that affects the arteries and can lead to narrowing or blockage, which can cause health problems such as heart attacks, stroke, and peripheral vascular disease. It occurs when there is damage or thickening in the inner lining of the arteries, which can reduce blood flow and increase the risk of clot formation. Artery disease can be caused by a variety of factors including smoking, high cholesterol levels, high blood pressure, diabetes, obesity, and physical inactivity. It is important to manage these risk factors through lifestyle changes, medication, and other treatments as recommended by a healthcare professional.

Pericarditis is a type of cardiovascular disease that affects the pericardium, which is the fibrous sac surrounding the heart. It is inflammation of the pericardium and can cause chest pain and other symptoms. Pericarditis is not the same as congestive heart failure (CHF) or dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM), although it can be a complication of these conditions.

That is correct. Peripheral artery disease, also known as peripheral vascular disease, is a condition where the blood vessels in your arms and legs become narrowed or blocked. This can lead to reduced blood flow to these areas, which can cause pain, cramping, or numbness in your extremities. It is often caused by a build-up of plaque in the arteries, which can be made up of cholesterol and other fatty substances. Risk factors for peripheral artery disease include smoking, high blood pressure, diabetes, and physical inactivity.

Familial encephalopathy with neuroserpin inclusion bodies (FENIB) is a type of autosomal dominant disease that affects the brain. It is characterized by intraneuronal inclusions of mutant neuroserpin, which leads to progressive encephalopathy, dementia and seizures. The condition has a material basis in a mutation in the SERPINI1 gene, which is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. FENIB is also known as familial encephalopathy with neuroserpin inclusion bodies (FENIB).

Pyrimidine metabolic disorder is a genetic condition that affects the way the body processes pyrimidines. Pyrimidines are important for the formation of DNA and RNA, which are necessary for the growth and development of all living organisms.

In individuals with pyrimidine metabolic disorder, there is a deficiency in one or more enzymes involved in pyrimidine metabolism. This leads to an accumulation of pyrimidines, which can cause various symptoms and health problems.

Pyrimidine metabolic disorders can be inherited from parents who pass on the genetic defects that cause them. They are relatively rare, but when they do occur, they can have serious consequences for an individual's health and well-being. Treatment options may include dietary changes, medications, and other interventions to manage symptoms and improve quality of life.
Orotic aciduria is a type of pyrimidine metabolic disorder. It is characterized by excessive secretion of orotic acid in urine.

Charge syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that affects many parts of the body, including the face, ears, eyes, heart, inner ear, and retina. It is caused by mutations in the CHRFA2 gene, which provides instructions for making a protein called chromodomain-helicase-binding protein A. This protein is involved in several important processes in the cell, such as DNA repair and regulation of gene expression.

People with Charge syndrome may have a combination of physical and developmental problems, including:

* Hearing and vision impairments
* Facial abnormalities, such as small or absent ears, cleft lip and palate, and low-set eyes
* Heart defects
* Ear infections and other health issues
* Delayed growth and development

Charge syndrome can also affect a person's behavior and cognitive function. Some individuals with the disorder may have autism spectrum disorder or other developmental delays. Early intervention and specialized care can help manage the symptoms and improve quality of life for people with Charge syndrome.
Generalized dystonia is a type of dystonia that affects most or all of the body. It is also known as familial dystonia and fragments of torsion dystonia. It is related to Dystonia 12.

Focal dystonia is a type of dystonia that affects a specific part of the body, as opposed to generalized dystonia which affects multiple muscle groups throughout the body. It is considered a localized form of dystonia and typically involves involuntary contractions or twisting movements in one or more muscles. The exact cause of focal dystonia is often difficult to determine and may be related to genetics, environmental factors, or injury to the affected muscle. Treatment options for focal dystonia may include medications, physical therapy, and sometimes surgery.
Multifocal dystonia is a type of dystonia that affects two or more unrelated body parts.

Segmental dystonia is a type of dystonia that affects two or more adjacent parts of the body. It is characterized by sustained muscle contractions, which can cause twisting and repetitive movements or abnormal postures. This type of dystonia can be caused by various factors, including genetic, environmental, and systemic conditions. Treatment options for segmental dystonia may include medications, physical therapy, and surgery, depending on the underlying cause and severity of the condition. It is important to consult with a healthcare professional for proper diagnosis and treatment.
Anismus is a condition characterized by the inability to relax the muscles of the pelvic floor during defecation, resulting in difficulty passing stools. It is considered a form of focal dystonia.

Cervical dystonia, also known as spasmodic torticollis, is a type of focal dystonia characterized by involuntary muscle contractions and spasms in the neck and shoulders. This condition can cause the head to twist or turn abnormally to one side or lead to an uncomfortable position that feels like a "pulling" sensation.

The specific cause of cervical dystonia is not always clear, but it may be linked to factors such as genetics, certain medications, or nerve damage. Treatment options for cervical dystonia vary depending on the severity and underlying causes; however, common treatments include physical therapy, botulinum toxin injections, medications, and surgery.

Focal hand dystonia, also known as organic writer's cramp, is a type of focal dystonia that affects a single muscle or small group of muscles in the hand. It occurs due to involuntary muscular contractions and can be caused by underlying medical conditions such as stroke or traumatic brain injury. Focal hand dystonia is different from generalised dystonia, which affects multiple muscle groups throughout the body. It can cause significant discomfort and limitation in movement, making it difficult for individuals to perform tasks that require fine motor skills. Treatment options may include medications, physical therapy, and sometimes surgery, depending on the severity of the condition and other factors.

Oculogyric crisis is a type of focal dystonia characterized by prolonged involuntary upward deviation of the eyes. It occurs due to excessive activation of dopamine in the basal ganglia, which leads to abnormal functioning of the extraocular muscles that control eye movement. Oculogyric crisis is a symptom of Parkinson's disease and other conditions that affect the basal ganglia. In some cases, it can also occur as a side effect of certain medications used to treat Parkinson's disease.

The condition is caused by a mutation in the HSPG2 gene, which provides instructions for making a protein called hyaluronan synthase 2. This protein is involved in the production of a thick, sticky substance called hyaluronan that helps to cushion and support joints and other tissues. When there is a mutation in the HSPG2 gene, it can lead to an excess of hyaluronan, which can cause the muscles to become stiff and difficult to move.
There is no known cure for Mast Syndrome, but treatment options may include physical therapy, medications to alleviate pain or spasticity, and assistive devices like walkers or wheelchairs to help with mobility. It's important for individuals with this condition to work closely with their healthcare providers to develop a personalized treatment plan that addresses their specific needs and symptoms.

Masa syndrome is a type of X-linked recessive disease that is characterized by hydrocephalus, spasticity of the lower limbs, adducted thumbs, aphasia, seizures, agenesis of the corpus callosum, and intellectual disability in the mild to moderate range. It has exact synonyms such as CRASH syndrome, Gareis-Mason syndrome, L1 syndrome, SPG1, X-linked complicated hereditary spastic paraplegia type 1, X-linked corpus callosum agenesis, and X-linked spastic paraplegia 1. It is also known as hereditary spastic paraplegia 1.
Smith Mc Cort Dysplasia is a medical condition characterized by short limbs and a short trunk with a barrel-shaped chest. It is also known as Dyggve-Melchior-Clausen disease.

Simpson-Golabi-Behmel Syndrome Type 1, also known as SGB Syndrome, is a rare genetic disorder that affects growth and development. It is characterized by pre- and postnatal overgrowth, craniofacial, skeletal, cardiac, and renal abnormalities. The syndrome has a material basis in mutation of the gene encoding glypican-3 (GPC3) on chromosome Xq26. It is also known as DGSX Golabi-Rosen Syndrome, Sara Angers Syndrome, Simpson dysmorphia syndrome, and X-linked dysplasia gigantism syndrome. Additionally, it is sometimes referred to as bulldog syndrome.

Scoliosis is a type of spinal disease characterized by an abnormal curvature of the spine. It can be caused by various factors such as genetics, poor posture, or injury. Scoliosis can lead to complications such as pain, limited mobility, and difficulty breathing if left untreated. Treatment options include bracing, physical therapy, and surgery, depending on the severity of the case.

It is the most common form of scoliosis, and can affect people of all ages, but it often begins during childhood or adolescence. Scoliosis is a condition where the spine curves to one side, but idiopathic scoliosis specifically refers to cases where no underlying cause can be identified.

sclerosteosis is a type of hyperostosis characterized by excessive bone formation in the skull, mandible, clavicle, ribs and diaphyses of long bones. It occurs throughout life and can be considered as a form of osteopetrosis.

Sclerocornea, also known as isolated congenital sclerocornea, is a type of corneal disease in which the cornea blends with the sclera, resulting in clouding of the cornea. It is a condition that is present at birth and can cause vision problems if not treated properly. Symptoms may include decreased vision, sensitivity to light, and a feeling of a foreign object in the eye. Treatment options for sclerocornea may include corrective surgery or other medical interventions to improve vision and reduce symptoms.
Scapuloperoneal myopathy is a type of muscular dystrophy that affects the shoulder and upper arm region, with symptoms appearing earlier and more severely than in the lower legs.

Robinow syndrome, also known as acral dysostosis with facial and genital abnormalities or fetal face syndrome, is a type of autosomal genetic disease that is characterized by mild to moderate short stature due to growth delays after birth, distinctive craniofacial abnormalities, skeletal malformations, and genital abnormalities. It has an exact synonym of Robinow dwarfism.

Rippling muscle disease 2, also known as autosomal dominant limb-girdle muscular dystrophy type 1C, is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle weakness and wasting. It is caused by mutations in the caveolin-3 gene (CAV3) on chromosome 3p25. The condition typically affects the shoulders, arms, legs, and pelvic region, and can also impact the heart and other organs. Treatment options may include physical therapy, medication to manage symptoms, and, in some cases, respiratory support. It is important for individuals with this condition to work closely with their healthcare provider to develop an appropriate treatment plan.

Dowling-Degos disease is a type of pigmentation disorder characterized by a reticulate pattern of abnormal skin coloration. This condition is more common in men than women and typically affects individuals in their 30s to 50s. The exact cause of Dowling-Degos disease is unknown, but it may be related to genetics or environmental factors such as sun exposure.
The symptoms of Dowling-Degos disease include a reticulate pattern of abnormal skin coloration, particularly in the body's folds and creases. The discoloration can also affect other areas of the body, including the arms, legs, chest, back, and scalp. In some cases, Dowling-Degos disease may also be associated with other medical conditions such as lupus or scleroderma.
There is no cure for Dowling-Degos disease, but treatment options may include topical steroids to reduce inflammation, hydroquinone cream to lighten the skin, and laser therapy to remove excess pigment. In severe cases, surgery may be necessary to remove affected skin.
It's important to note that Dowling-Degos disease is not a common condition, and most people with this disorder have a good prognosis with appropriate treatment. However, it's always recommended to consult a dermatologist or other healthcare professional for a proper diagnosis and treatment plan.

dyschromatosis symmetrica hereditaria is a type of pigmentation disease.
dyschromatosis symmetrica hereditaria is characterized by progressively pigmented and depigmented macules, often mixed in a reticulate pattern, concentrated on the dorsal extremities. It has the exact synonym "reticulate acropigmentation of Dohi".

Reticulate acropigmentation of Kitamura is a pigmentation disorder that causes lesions to appear on the skin. These lesions usually start as light-colored, reticulated macules on the back of the hands and feet. Over time, these lesions may darken and spread, eventually appearing on other parts of the body. Along with the darkening of the lesions, there may be pitting on the palms and soles of the feet, as well as disruption of dermatoglyphics. This condition is also known by the acronym RAPK.

Renal hepatic pancreatic dysplasia, also known as Ivemark's syndrome, is a rare and severe genetic disorder that affects multiple organ systems, including the kidneys, liver, pancreas, and gastrointestinal tract. It is characterized by pancreatic fibrosis, renal dysplasia (abnormal development of the kidneys), and hepatic dysgenesis (abnormal development or function of the liver). The disorder usually leads to fatal complications soon after birth.

Ptosis is a medical condition characterized by the drooping or hanging of the upper eyelid. It can also affect the lower eyelid, resulting in a total drooping of both eyelids. Ptosis can be caused by various factors such as aging, muscle weakness, or damage to the nerve that controls the eyelid muscles.

Ptosis is typically diagnosed through a physical examination and may require further testing if additional symptoms are present, such as difficulty opening the eye or vision problems. Treatment options for ptosis include medical therapies, surgical procedures, or a combination of both. The best approach will depend on the underlying cause of the condition and the severity of the ptosis.

It is essential to consult an ophthalmologist for proper diagnosis and treatment of ptosis to prevent further complications and ensure good vision and eye health.

Congenital ptosis is a type of ptosis that occurs at birth or during infancy due to abnormal development of the eyelid muscles. It can affect one or both eyes and may cause difficulty in opening the eye properly. Treatment options for congenital ptosis include surgical procedures, such as blepharoplasty or frontalis sling procedure, to correct the droopy eyelids and restore normal function.

Gallbladder disease refers to a condition where the gallbladder, a small organ located in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen, becomes inflamed or swollen. It can also be referred to as cholecystitis, which is an acute inflammation of the gallbladder.
Gallbladder disease is not the same as other diseases, but rather a specific condition that affects the functioning of the gallbladder. The gallbladder's primary role is to store and release bile, which helps in digestion. However, when the gallbladder becomes inflamed or swollen, it can cause discomfort, pain, and other symptoms.
Gallbladder disease can be caused by various factors, including blockages due to stones or sludge, infections, and certain medications. It is important to consult a healthcare professional if you experience any of the symptoms associated with gallbladder disease, such as severe pain in the right upper quadrant, nausea, vomiting, fever, chills, or jaundice.

porencephaly is a type of brain disease that occurs when the brainstem and cerebellum are affected. It can cause a variety of symptoms, including balance and coordination problems, difficulty swallowing, and speech difficulties. Treatment for porencephaly typically focuses on managing the symptoms and improving quality of life.

Pontocerebellar hypoplasia (PCH) is a type of neurodegenerative disease characterized by underdevelopment or insufficient development of the pons and cerebellum. This condition can result in various symptoms depending on the extent of the brain damage, including ataxia, dystonia, tremors, and difficulty with balance and coordination. PCH is often diagnosed in childhood and can be caused by genetic or environmental factors. Treatment options for PCH are limited and may include physical therapy, medications to manage symptoms, and supportive care.

Pontocerebellar hypoplasia type 1a is a type of autosomal recessive disease that affects the cerebellum and causes various symptoms such as central and peripheral motor dysfunction, hypotonia, spasticity, and failure to thrive. It has a material basis in homozygous or compound heterozygous mutations in the VRK1 gene.

Pontocerebellar hypoplasia type 1b is a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the EXOSC3 gene. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means that to develop the disease, a person must inherit two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent). Symptoms typically appear during infancy and childhood and can include problems with balance, coordination, and movement. Additionally, affected individuals may experience developmental delays, seizures, and a small head size (microcephaly).

Pontocerebellar hypoplasia type 2a is a type of autosomal recessive disease characterized by progressive microcephaly, chorea, epilepsy, and hyperreflexia. It has a material basis in the autosomal recessive inheritance of mutation in the TSEN54 gene.

pontocerebellar hypoplasia type 2b is a severe condition characterized by progressive microcephaly, clonus, dysphagia and failure to thrive. It has a material basis in autosomal recessive inheritance and is caused by mutations in the TSEN2 gene.

Pontocerebellar hypoplasia type 2c is indeed a rare genetic disorder that affects the cerebellum, which is responsible for controlling balance and coordination. It is caused by mutations in the TSEN34 gene, which encodes a protein called TDP-43. This protein plays a crucial role in the regulation of RNA metabolism and is involved in several neurodegenerative diseases.

In individuals with pontocerebellar hypoplasia type 2c, there is a loss of Purkinje cells, which are responsible for coordinating movements and maintaining balance. This leads to severe motor coordination problems and an ataxic gait. Additionally, affected individuals often experience extrapyramidal dyskinesia, seizures, and failure to thrive due to impaired feeding and swallowing.

As it is a recessive disorder, pontocerebellar hypoplasia type 2c can only be passed down from affected parents to their offspring. It is essential for families with a history of this condition to seek genetic counseling to understand the risks and options available for managing their health and preventing passing on the disorder to future generations.

Pontocerebellar hypoplasia type 2d (also known as SEPS, SEPSECS) is a rare genetic disorder that affects the cerebellum and brainstem. It is caused by mutations in the SEPSECS gene, which provides instructions for making a protein called Septin-9. The protein plays a role in maintaining the structure and function of the cerebellum and brainstem, and when it is missing or altered, it can lead to abnormal development and the symptoms associated with pontocerebellar hypoplasia type 2d.

Symptoms typically appear during infancy or early childhood and may include:

* Progressive microcephaly (a small head size)
* Profound intellectual disability
* Spasticity (increased muscle tone and difficulty moving)
* Seizures
* Developmental delays

There is no cure for pontocerebellar hypoplasia type 2d, but early intervention and specialized care can help manage the symptoms. Genetic counseling may be recommended for individuals and families affected by this condition to understand the risk of recurrence and genetic testing to confirm the diagnosis.

Pontocerebellar hypoplasia type 2e is a severe and rare form of pontocerebellar hypoplasia, characterized by progressive microcephaly (a smaller than average head size), profound intellectual disability, spasticity (stiffness and difficulty moving due to damage or dysfunction in the brain or spinal cord), and seizures. It is caused by mutations in the VPS53 gene, which is located on the X chromosome. Pontocerebellar hypoplasia type 3 is a type of pontocerebellar hypoplasia that is characterized by progressive microcephaly, hypotonia, dysmorphic features, profound intellectual disability and seizure. It has a material basis in autosomal recessive inheritance of mutation in the PCLO gene.

Pontocerebellar hypoplasia type 6 is a specific subtype of pontocerebellar hypoplasia, characterized by olivopontocerebellar hypoplasia and developmental delay. This condition is caused by an autosomal recessive inheritance of mutation in the RARS2 gene.

Pontocerebellar hypoplasia type 7, also known as TOE1-related pontocerebellar hypoplasia, is a genetic disorder characterized by several distinct features. These include delayed psychomotor development, hypotonia (low muscle tone), gonadal abnormalities, and respiratory failure. The condition is caused by a mutation in the TOE1 gene, which is located on the X chromosome. Due to the nature of this genetic disorder, it typically affects males more severely than females, as they have only one functioning copy of the gene (XY0). In contrast, females have two copies of the gene (XX), and may only experience mild symptoms if any. The prognosis for pontocerebellar hypoplasia type 7 can vary widely depending on the severity of the symptoms and the overall health of the individual. However, with proper medical care and support, individuals with this condition can lead fulfilling lives despite their challenges.

Pontocerebellar hypoplasia type 9 (also known as AMPD2-associated pontocerebellar hypoplasia) is a specific form of pontocerebellar hypoplasia characterized by progressive microcephaly, spasticity, seizures, and brain atrophy. It is caused by autosomal recessive inheritance of a mutation in the AMPD2 gene, which encodes the mitochondrial enzyme AMP-dependent protein kinase D (AMPK Delta 2). This enzyme plays a crucial role in regulating energy metabolism and cellular function. Mutations in this gene can lead to disruptions in these processes, ultimately resulting in the developmental and neurological abnormalities seen in pontocerebellar hypoplasia type 9.

Primary pigmented nodular adrenocortical disease, often abbreviated as PPNAD, is a specific type of adrenal cortex disease characterized by small to normal-sized adrenal glands containing multiple small cortical pigmented nodules. These nodules are usually benign and produce excess amounts of steroid hormones such as cortisol or aldosterone, leading to hypercortisolism or hyperaldosteronism respectively. PPNAD is also sometimes referred to as Conn's syndrome after the doctor who first described it in 1958.

Photosensitive epilepsy is a type of epilepsy characterized by seizures that are triggered by visual stimuli, such as flashing lights. It is also known as photogenic epilepsy or photoparoxysmal response.

Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV) is a congenital disorder characterized by abnormal development of the vitreous humor, which is the clear, jelly-like substance that fills the inner part of the eye. PHPV is typically diagnosed in infancy or early childhood and can cause problems with vision, such as strabismus (crossed eyes) and leukocoria (white pupils). It is a type of developmental vitreous disease and is caused by abnormal development of the vitreous humor due to a failure of the primary vitreous and hyaloid vasculature to regress during embryological development. PHPV can also lead to other complications, such as retinal detachment and traction retinal detachment, which can cause vision loss if left untreated. Treatment options may include surgical interventions, such as vitrectomy, or other eye care management strategies depending on the severity of the condition and individual patient needs.

Peeling skin syndrome, also known as familial continuous skin peeling disease or keratosis exfoliativa congenita, is a rare genetic disorder that affects the epidermal cells. It causes the top layer of skin to slowly and progressively peel off without any pain or itching. The condition can be inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means that a child must inherit two copies of the gene (one from each parent) to develop the disease.
Peeling skin syndrome is not contagious and does not spread from person to person. It can affect people of all ages but is more common in children. The condition may be mistaken for other skin conditions, such as eczema or psoriasis, but it is unique in its presentation. Treatment options include topical creams and ointments, ultraviolet light therapy, and surgery in severe cases.

Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is a type of hemolytic anemia that occurs due to the acquired deficiency in the cell membrane glycosyl phosphatidylinositols (GPI). This defect makes red blood cells more susceptible to complement-mediated lysis, leading to the breakdown of red blood cells and causing symptoms such as abdominal pain, hematuria, esophageal dysmotility, and thrombosis. PNH is classified as an acquired hemolytic anemia and is characterized by its unique combination of clinical features that set it apart from other types of hemolytic anemia.

Parietal foramina is a type of neural tube defect that occurs when the parietal bones in a baby's skull fail to develop properly during fetal development. This results in an abnormal opening or hole in the skull, which can cause various problems such as increased intracranial pressure and potential brain damage if left untreated. Parietal foramina has a material basis in mutations in the ALX4 gene or MSX2 gene, which are genes involved in the development of cranial bones.
It is also known as hereditary cranium bifidum and enlarged parietal foramina. It's essential to have proper prenatal care and screening to detect this condition early and receive appropriate treatment.

Combined Oxidative Phosphorylation Deficiency (COPD) is a rare genetic disorder that affects the body's ability to produce energy. It is characterized by a combination of features, including growth retardation, microcephaly, hypertonia, encephalopathy, cardiomyopathy, and liver dysfunction. These symptoms can vary in severity from mild to severe and can lead to lifelong disability if not treated properly. It is important for individuals with COPD to work closely with their healthcare provider to manage their condition and ensure the best possible outcomes.

The cornea plays an essential role in vision by helping to focus light onto the retina and providing some protection against environmental factors such as dust and UV rays. There are many types of corneal diseases, ranging from mild to severe, that can cause a variety of symptoms including blurred or double vision, sensitivity to light, eye pain, and even blindness if left untreated. Some common examples include Fuchs' dystrophy, keratoconus, and corneal transplant rejection.
